docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-13 Reform Eludes Iraqi Police Shiite militiamen and criminals entrenched throughout Iraq's police and internal security forces are resisting recent efforts by some Iraqi leaders and the American military to root them out and help win the trust of skeptical Sunni Arabs, Iraqi and Western officials say. 1 Dozens more bodies have been discovered in Baghdad, bringing the four-day total to at least 165 and prompting some Sunni Arab leaders to raise new questions about the recent security operation intended to take back Baghdad from the insurgents, deaths squads and militias who have been waging sectarian warfare. 4 Vatican Expresses Regret A top Vatican official said Pope Benedict XVI ''deeply regretted'' that a speech he made last week ''sounded offensive to the sensibility of Muslim believers.'' 3 U.S. Urges Banking Scrutiny The United States pressed the top finance officials of the world's leading industrial nations to crack down on what Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said was the exploitation of their banking systems by Iranian front companies involved in illicit activities. 8 South Africans Wage Taxi War Thousands of South African taxi owners, drivers and passengers have been killed and many more have been wounded in a guerrilla war between rival cartels that control thousands of low-cost minibuses that haul a large share of South Africa's urban commuters. 13 Drugs May Prevent Diabetes Drug therapy can prevent the development of Type 2 diabetes in millions of people who are at high risk for the disease, a major study suggests, potentially opening a new path for curbing a worldwide epidemic. The study involved about 5,000 people in 21 countries. 10 NATIONAL 14-32 Democrats' Ads Focus on Bush President Bush has become the marquee name in the Democrats' advertisement war. He is posed standing alone and next to Republican senators and members of Congress, and Republicans candidates are damned in the advertisements by the number of times they have voted with Mr. Bush in Congress. 1 Less Support for Renters As billions in housing aid begins to flow in New Orleans, most of it will go to homeowners. The renters of New Orleans, who once accounted for more than half the city's population, are on their own. 14 A Plague of Sticker Graffiti For several months someone has been plastering San Francisco's walls, public phones and newspaper boxes with postcard-size stickers reading ''BNE'' in big black letters, making him one of the most wanted people in the city. The mayor has offered a $2,500 reward for his capture. 14 Priests Hear of Abuse Hundreds of priests in the Philadelphia Archdiocese were summoned by the cardinal to hear from two adults who as children were molested by priests. The meeting was called to help teach members of the clergy about victims' struggles to rebuild their lives. 23 Tracking Tainted Spinach Packaged spinach salad disappeared from store shelves across the country, as investigators searched for the source of bacterial contamination that has now sickened more than 100 people and led to one death in Wisconsin. 20 Staying on Parents' Insurance Children can now stay on their parents' health insurance plans well into their 20's in a growing number of states. The trend stems from a concern that a healthy -- and profitable -- segment of the population is dropping out of the insurance pool. 1 NEW YORK/REGION 37-41 Tenants for the Freedom Tower The federal and New York State governments have tentatively agreed to serve as anchor tenants in the Freedom Tower, the tallest, most symbolic and most scrutinized skyscraper project at Ground Zero, under a plan expected to be announced today by Mayor Bloomberg and the governors of New York and New Jersey. 1 Youth Killed by Police Officer A police officer shot and killed an 18-year-old youth near a darkened East Harlem basketball court. Police officials defended the shooting, saying it appeared that the officer had fired in self-defense, but outraged residents insisted that the shooting was unprovoked. 38 Chess 41 Weather 42

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Jonathan Rauch's review of ''The Party of Death: The Democrats, the Media, the Courts, and the Disregard for Human Life,'' by Ramesh Ponnuru (Sept. 3), endorses Ponnuru's claim that because ''abortion-rights absolutists ... would allow abortions even in the latest stages of pregnancy ... their position gives them no firm purchase from which to oppose infanticide.'' This overlooks a point routinely made in introductory philosophy courses on moral problems: Having a right to life does not entail having a right to everything one needs in order to stay alive. If it did, sick people would have a right to blood transfusions and bone marrow transplants from unwilling donors and everyone would have a right to whatever medical care he needed in order to stay alive, making the Republican Party the party of death for opposing national health insurance. Felicia Nimue Ackerman Providence, R.I. The writer is a professor of philosophy at Brown University.
docs.abstract: Felicia Nimue Ackerman letter comments on Jonathan Rauch Sept 3 review of Ramesh Ponnuru book The Party of Death: The Democrats, the Media, the Courts, and the Disregard for Human Life

docs.lead_paragraph: Not only are children moving back home after college and asking Mom and Dad for monthly subsidies, but in a growing number of states children can now stay on their parents' health insurance plans well into their 20's. Call it another example of adultescence. With 18- to 34-year-olds the fastest growing group of uninsured, states are extending the time that children can be a dependent for insurance purposes.

headline.main: For Insurance, Adult Children Ride Piggyback

docs.abstract: More states are extending time that children can be dependent for health insurance purposes in recognition of fact that 18- to 34-year-olds are fastest growing group of uninsured; trend stems from concern that healthy and profitable segment of population is dropping out of insurance pool; about 30 percent of adults ages 18 to 24 and more than one-quarter of adults ages 25 to 34 are uninsured, due to rising cost of health insurance premiums and fewer jobs offering full benefits; graph; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: After one of the more intensive grass-roots campaigns that Albany has seen in years, the State Senate voted yesterday to require that health insurance plans cover treatment for mental illness.

headline.main: Pataki Casts Doubt on Fate of Mental Health Measure Passed by the Senate

docs.lead_paragraph: Who wants to buy a big, glassy gherkin?

headline.main: One Giant Pickle, Slightly Used, For Sale

docs.abstract: Who wants to buy a big, glassy gherkin? Swiss Re, the insurance giant, has decided to put its highly recognizable 40-story skyscraper in London up for sale. Designed by Lord Norman Foster and completed in 2004, the tower has already become a landmark of London's financial district. The asking price for the building - known [...]
